You said:
okay so rn this is how the webpage looks like, the images are overlapping the text a little and i feel like theres not enough space in between all the different sections. how can i fix this while not adding on extra things because she is strict and she wants it exactly like the instructions
ChatGPT said:

Nice that screenshot explains it. The images arent wrong, theyre just inline with the paragraph above and the heading below, so the surrounding text gets cramped.

You dont need anything fancy or a separate CSS file to fix this two tiny, safe changes will make the page look neat while keeping the HTML minimal (what strict graders like).

Pick one of the two options below and do exactly what it says in VS Code.

OPTION A Keep images side-by-side but give space above/below

This keeps the two pictures next to each other but forces them into their own block so text wont wrap around them, and adds a small vertical gap after them.

Replace your two <img ...> lines with this (copy/paste exactly):

html
<!-- images placed in local images/ folder -->
<div style="margin:20px 0 30px 0;">
  <img src="images/breakfast.jpg" alt="Breakfast platter with eggs and toast" width="300">
  <img src="images/breakfast2.jpg" alt="Various breakfast foods on a table" width="300">
</div>

Why this works:

  • <div> is a block element so the paragraph above ends before the images and the next heading/table starts after the div.

  • style="margin:20px 0 30px 0;" adds a little vertical spacing above/below so sections dont touch (very small, unobtrusive inline style).

OPTION B Stack the images one under the other (simplest)

If you prefer the images stacked vertically (no side-by-side), use this instead:

html
<!-- images placed in local images/ folder -->
<p><img src="images/breakfast.jpg" alt="Breakfast platter with eggs and toast" width="300"></p>
<p><img src="images/breakfast2.jpg" alt="Various breakfast foods on a table" width="300"></p>

Why this works:

  • Each <p> creates its own line and natural browser spacing, so images wont overlap or crowd headings/tables.

  • No inline styles required.

Exactly where to paste

  1. Open csce242/assignments/01-basic-html/index.html in VS Code.

  2. Find the two <img src="images/"> lines you currently have.

  3. Replace those two lines with the block from Option A or Option B.

  4. Save the file (Ctrl/Cmd + S).

Preview (one minute)

  1. In File Explorer/Finder go to:
    Desktop mahipatelr.github.io csce242 assignments 01-basic-html

  2. Double-click index.html to open in your browser.

  3. Check that:

    • images no longer overlap the paragraph above

    • theres visible space between the images and the following heading/table

    • layout looks tidy and simple

Final notes (to keep instructor happy)

  • These changes are minimal, purely structural (no external styling), and keep the page true to the assignment.

  • Inline style is tiny and safe used only in Option A to add modest spacing; Option B avoids styles entirely.

  • If you want the spacing slightly larger/smaller, change the 20px / 30px numbers in Option A (but you dont need to).

Tell me which option you used and paste a short done message (for example: Done Option A). Ill double-check the exact HTML you now have and then walk you through pushing the final site to GitHub.

You said:
okay yes the images are good!! and now i feel like each section looks really crowded together
ChatGPT said:

Youre noticing exactly the right thing and youre also right to be careful because your instructor is strict.

The good news:
You can fix the crowded look using 100% valid, minimal HTML
No CSS file, no extra features, nothing outside the instructions

Below are two instructor-safe options.
I recommend Option A first.

OPTION A (BEST & SAFEST): Use headings + natural spacing + <hr>

The <hr> tag creates a horizontal line and adds natural vertical spacing.
It is pure HTML, very common in intro classes, and not considered extra.

What to do (step by step)

  1. Open

    css
    csce242  assignments  01-basic-html  index.html

  2. Find where one section ends and the next section starts.

For example, after your images block, add this line:

html
<hr>

  1. Do the same between major sections, like this:

Example layout (copy the idea, not everything):

html
<h1>The Importance of Breakfast</h1>

<p>...</p>
<p>...</p>

<div style="margin:20px 0 30px 0;">
    <img src="images/breakfast.jpg" alt="Breakfast platter with eggs and toast" width="300">
    <img src="images/breakfast2.jpg" alt="Various breakfast foods on a table" width="300">
</div>

<hr>

<h2>Popular Breakfast Combinations</h2>

<ul>
    <li>Eggs and toast</li>
    <li>Yogurt with fruit and granola</li>
    <li>Cereal and milk</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h2>Breakfast Schedule</h2>

<table border="1">
    ...
</table>

<hr>

<h2>Learn More About Breakfast</h2>

<ul>
    ...
</ul>

Why this is safe

  • <hr> is HTML only

  • Adds spacing automatically

  • Clearly separates sections

  • Very common in beginner assignments

  • No styling, no layout tricks

OPTION B (EVEN SIMPLER): Use <br><br> between sections

If you dont want lines, you can just add vertical space.

Example:

html
<br><br>

<h2>Popular Breakfast Combinations</h2>

You can do this between sections:

html
</ul>

<br><br>

<h2>Breakfast Schedule</h2>

Why this is also okay

  • <br> is basic HTML

  • Adds breathing room

  • No styling

  • Very beginner-friendly

Dont overdo it 2 <br> tags max between sections.

What NOT to do (good instincts on your part)

Do not:

  • Add a CSS file

  • Add fancy layouts

  • Use margins everywhere

  • Use <section> with styling

  • Use flexbox/grid

  • Add extra headings just for spacing

You are correct to avoid these.

My recommendation for a strict instructor

Use <hr> between major sections
Keep your existing headings (h1, h2)
Leave everything else as is

That gives:

  • clear separation

  • clean structure

  • zero risk

Next tiny step

Add <hr> between your sections, save, refresh the page.

Then reply with:
Spacing looks good now.

After that, well do the final step: pushing everything to GitHub and checking the live link one last time before submission.

You said:
okay and for the table do i need borders?
ChatGPT said:

Great question and youre right to double-check this for a strict class.

Short answer (clear + safe)

YES, you should include borders on the table.

Including borders is the safest choice for this assignment.

Why borders are recommended (for your class)

Your assignment says:

1 table (min 2 columns and 3 rows)

It does not explicitly say add borders, BUT in intro HTML classes:

  • Borders make the table clearly visible

  • Graders can instantly see rows and columns

  • Many instructors expect borders at this level

If you dont add borders:

  • The table technically exists

  • BUT it can look like plain text

  • A strict grader might say: Table not clearly shown

So borders = zero risk.

The correct, simple way to add borders (HTML-only)

Use this exact syntax (you already have it which is good):

html
<table border="1">

Thats it.
No CSS. No styling. Completely acceptable in beginner HTML.

Example (what you should already have)

html
<h2>Breakfast Schedule</h2>

<table border="1">
    <tr>
        <th>Day</th>
        <th>Breakfast Time</th>
    </tr>
    <tr>
        <td>Monday/Wednesday</td>
        <td>9:00 AM</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
        <td>Tuesday/Thursday</td>
        <td>7:30 AM</td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
        <td>Friday/Saturday/Sunday</td>
        <td>10:00 AM</td>
    </tr>
</table>

This clearly shows:

  • 2 columns

  • 3+ rows

  • Proper table structure

  • Easy-to-grade visual layout

What NOT to do (youre right to avoid this)

Dont remove borders
Dont add CSS just for the table
Dont over-style it

At this stage, simple and obvious beats modern and fancy.

Final reassurance

  • Borders are allowed

  • Borders are expected

  • Borders help you not lose points

  • You already did this correctly

Next step (last content check)

Reply with:
Table has borders and looks clear.

Then well move on to the final submission steps (GitHub push + exact links to submit).

also they wanted two paragraphs but on the webpage all the sentences are squished together
ChatGPT said:

Excellent this is exactly the right final checklist thinking before submission.
Lets fix both issues cleanly, without adding anything extra or risky.

Ill go point by point and be very explicit.

ISSUE 1: I dont see the HTML comment

This is NORMAL and IMPORTANT to understand

HTML comments do NOT appear on the webpage. Ever.

Thats why you dont see it.

This is what your instructor means by:

An html comment, indicating your name and the course

They mean in the CODE, not on the page.

What you need to confirm (in VS Code)

Open this file:

css
csce242  assignments  01-basic-html  index.html

At the top, you should see something like this:

html
<!-- Assignment 01 - Mahi Patel - CSCE 242 -->

If that line exists anywhere in the file (usually right after <body>),
you are 100% meeting this requirement.

It is not supposed to show on the website.

So:

  • Not visible on webpage = correct

  • Visible in code = correct

Youre good here

ISSUE 2: My list does not show bullets or numbers

This one does need a small fix, and its simple.

Why your list looks wrong

From your screenshot earlier, your Popular Breakfast Combinations section looked like plain text, meaning the items were probably written like this:

html
Eggs and toast
Yogurt with fruit and granola
Cereal and milk

That is NOT an HTML list.

The correct way to make a list (required)

You must use either:

  • <ul> bulleted list

  • <ol> numbered list

SAFEST OPTION: Bulleted list (<ul>)

Replace your current list text with this exact code:

html
<h2>Popular Breakfast Combinations</h2>

<ul>
    <li>Eggs and toast</li>
    <li>Yogurt with fruit and granola</li>
    <li>Cereal and milk</li>
</ul>

Now you will see:

  • bullets

  • at least 3 items

  • a clearly recognizable HTML list

This fully satisfies:

1 numeric or bulleted list (min 3 bullets)

ISSUE 3: Two paragraphs but sentences look squished

This is a visual misunderstanding, not a requirement problem but well clean it up so its obvious.

Why this happens

HTML does not care about line breaks inside a paragraph.

This:

html
<p>
Sentence one.
Sentence two.
Sentence three.
Sentence four.
</p>

Will always display as one paragraph block, which is correct.

Your instructor checks:

  • Are there two <p> tags?

  • Does each contain 4+ sentences?

They do NOT check spacing inside the paragraph.

How to make it look clearer (optional but safe)

If you want the paragraphs to visually feel less squished, make sure you have two separate <p> tags, like this:

html
<p>
Breakfast is known to be the most important meal of the day. The meal provides energy
and nutrients for the body as people report feeling more focused and alert throughout
the day. Building a routine with starting off each morning with a balanced breakfast
can lead to increased productivity. Whereas, skipping breakfast can lead to fatigue
and lack of motivation.
</p>

<p>
Some popular breakfast foods include eggs, yogurt, fruit, oatmeal, toast, pancakes,
waffles, and smoothies. Eating a combination of these foods makes a more nutritious
breakfast. A balanced breakfast of various food groups supports a healthy lifestyle.
The food groups include fruits, vegetables, grains, protein, and dairy.
</p>

That is perfect.

You do NOT need:

  • <br> inside paragraphs

  • extra spacing tricks

  • CSS

Two <p> tags = two paragraphs

FINAL RUBRIC CHECK (YOU ARE PASSING)

Lets check everything now:

  • Doctype and structure

  • Proper formatting & indentation

  • HTML comment with name & course (in code)

  • <title> tag

  • <h1> main heading

  • Two <p> paragraphs, 4+ sentences each

  • 2 images, sized

  • Bulleted list (now fixed)

  • Table with borders, 2 columns, 3+ rows

  • 2 external links

Nothing missing. Nothing extra. Nothing risky.

What to do RIGHT NOW

  1. Fix the list using <ul><li></li></ul>

  2. Save the file

  3. Refresh the browser

Then reply with:
List shows bullets now and paragraphs are correct.

After that, well do the final step:
pushing to GitHub and confirming the exact submission links so you dont lose points.

okay so i need to also do this, i have made the pdf and everything but how do i link it into vs code and everything step by step once again please? What Do You Need to Do: Create a pdf document containing the following information: The name of your website The description of your topic: must contain at least 5 sentences A list of each of the page names (Note: About Us would be a page, but login would not (That's more like a popup feature). A description of the data you will be storing, manipulating and viewing. Go Into details, e.g. We will be storing a list of tools (Tool name, description, price, producer, ...). Only the administrator will be able to add / edit / delete, so we will need user accounts with login security. Projects Folder on GitHub Add a 'projects' folder on github Inside the 'projects' folder add a 'part1' folder You will put a link to your pdf Submit a link that goes directly to your project part1's pdf on github Grading: -25% Late Each section is worth 25%, make sure to provide all the necessary information Submission
ChatGPT said:

Great youre almost there. Since you already made the PDF, Ill walk you through exact, baby-step instructions to:

  1. add the PDF into your GitHub repo (in projects/part1) using VS Code + Git (recommended),

  2. push it to GitHub, and

  3. get the exact link you should submit that goes directly to the PDF on GitHub.

Ill also include a simple alternative using GitHub Desktop and the HTML snippet if you want to link the PDF from one of your site pages.

Ill assume your local project root is the folder you already used:

bash
Desktop/mahipatelr.github.io

and your repo remote on GitHub is:

arduino
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io.git

A Put the PDF into the right local folder (one-time, small steps)

  1. Locate your PDF file on your computer (wherever you saved it). Let's call it part1-info.pdf.

  2. Open File Explorer / Finder and go to:

    lua
    Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io

  3. Inside that folder, create the required folders projects/part1:

    • Right-click New Folder name it projects

    • Open projects Right-click New Folder name it part1
      You now have:

    bash
    mahipatelr.github.io/projects/part1/

  4. Copy (or move) your part1-info.pdf into:

    bash
    mahipatelr.github.io/projects/part1/part1-info.pdf

  5. Open VS Code (if not open) and open the folder mahipatelr.github.io (File Open Folder select that folder).
    In the Explorer you should now see:

    nginx
    projects
   part1
       part1-info.pdf

B Commit & push using Git in VS Code (recommended)

If you have not installed Git, install it (https://git-scm.com/) then continue. If you prefer GitHub Desktop, skip to section D.

  1. In VS Code: Terminal New Terminal. Make sure the terminal path shows your project root (e.g., .../mahipatelr.github.io).

  2. Stage the new file:

    bash
    git add projects/part1/part1-info.pdf

    (or git add . to add everything changed)

  3. Commit the change:

    sql
    git commit -m "Add projects/part1/part1-info.pdf (project part1 document)"

  4. Push to GitHub (main branch). If your repo already uses main:

    perl
    git push

    If you need to set the remote or branch the first time:

    less
    git remote add origin https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io.git   # only if not set
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

    Follow any authentication prompts.

  5. Wait ~3090 seconds for GitHub to process the file.

C Get the direct link to the PDF on GitHub (exact URL you should submit)

  1. Go to your repo in the browser:

    arduino
    https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io

  2. Click the projects folder then part1 then click your part1-info.pdf file.

  3. On that PDF page GitHub shows a preview and a few buttons.
    Two link options you can submit choose the one your instructor wants:

  • (A) GitHub file page (blob) visible in GitHub UI (works fine):

    ruby
    https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/projects/part1/part1-info.pdf

    Replace main with master if your repo uses master.

  • (B) Direct file (raw) link opens the PDF directly in browser (sometimes preferred):

    • On the PDF preview page click the Raw button (or click the ... menu and choose View raw).

    • The raw link looks like:

      ruby
      https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/main/projects/part1/part1-info.pdf

    Use whichever link your instructor asked for. If they said direct link to the PDF, prefer the raw link (B). If they said link to your project part1s pdf on GitHub, the blob link (A) is also acceptable.

D Alternative: Use GitHub Desktop (GUI) to add & push

If you prefer GUI instead of terminal:

  1. Open GitHub Desktop.

  2. File Add Local Repository select the local folder mahipatelr.github.io.

  3. Youll see changed files in Changes (including projects/part1/part1-info.pdf).

  4. At the bottom-left enter commit message, e.g.:
    Add project part1 PDF

  5. Click Commit to main (or current branch).

  6. Click Push origin at the top.

  7. Wait a minute, then follow the same steps in section C to get the blob/raw link.

E Optional: Add a link to the PDF from your website (one-line HTML)

If you want the PDF to be reachable from your class portal or assignment page, add this exact line to whichever HTML file you want (for example, the main page csce242/index.html or assignment page):

html
<p><a href="/projects/part1/part1-info.pdf" target="_blank">Project Part1 PDF</a></p>

Notes:

  • The leading / (absolute path) points to the repo root when served by GitHub Pages, so the link becomes:

    bash
    https://mahipatelr.github.io/projects/part1/part1-info.pdf

  • If you prefer the GitHub UI link instead, use the blob URL:

    html
    <a href="https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/projects/part1/part1-info.pdf" target="_blank">Project Part1 PDF on GitHub</a>

If you add this line to an HTML file, save and push the HTML change as well (git add, commit, push).

F Checklist before you submit the link

  1. Confirm file is in GitHub at:
    https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/tree/main/projects/part1
    (this shows the folder and file)

  2. Click the PDF and copy either:

    • blob link: https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/projects/part1/part1-info.pdf

    • raw link: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/main/projects/part1/part1-info.pdf

  3. Submit whichever URL your instructor requires.

Common gotchas & troubleshooting (quick)

  • Branch name replace main above with master if thats your repo branch.

  • Case sensitivity filenames are case sensitive on GitHub (Part1-Info.pdf part1-info.pdf).

  • Wait a minute after pushing for GitHub to show the file.

  • If the raw link returns 404, open the PDF in GitHub, click Raw, and copy that exact URL.

If you want, I can do one of the following next reply with the exact phrase for what you want now:

  • Show me VS Code git commands Ill walk terminal commands step-by-step and what to expect.

  • Show me GitHub Desktop steps Ill give precise GUI clicks in sequence.

  • Check my link paste the blob/raw link you copied and Ill verify its correct and ready to submit.

You said:
i named it Project Part 1 - Topic Selection - CSCE 242 - Mahi Patel
ChatGPT said:

Nice that filename is descriptive and perfect for a document, but for GitHub and links its safer to remove spaces and very long punctuation. Ill walk you through everything you need now in tiny, exact steps: rename the file to a safe filename, put it into the projects/part1 folder, push it to GitHub, and copy the exact link you should submit.

Do each step in order. Ill give both the VS Code / Git commands and the GitHub Desktop / Explorer alternatives so you can pick whats easiest.

1) Rename the file to a safe filename (very important)

Why: GitHub and URLs are easier to work with when filenames have no spaces and are lowercase. Well use:

project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

Option A Rename in File Explorer / Finder

  1. Open File Explorer (Windows) or Finder (Mac).

  2. Go to the folder where your PDF currently is.

  3. Right-click the file Project Part 1 - Topic Selection - CSCE 242 - Mahi Patel.pdf Rename

  4. Replace the name with:

    project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  5. Press Enter.

Option B Rename in VS Code

  1. In VS Code Explorer, find the PDF file.

  2. Right-click it Rename.

  3. Type:

    project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  4. Press Enter.

Confirm the file shows that new name.

2) Put the file into the correct folder: projects/part1/

If you already created projects/part1 inside your repo, move/copy the renamed PDF there.

Option A Move with File Explorer / Finder

  1. Cut (or copy) project-part1-topic-selection.pdf.

  2. Navigate to:

    lua
    Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io  projects  part1

    (Create projects and part1 if they dont exist.)

  3. Paste the file into part1.

Option B Move in VS Code

  1. Drag the file in the Explorer panel from its current location into:

    nginx
    projects  part1

  2. If projects/part1 doesnt exist, right-click mahipatelr.github.io New Folder projects then inside it New Folder part1. Then drag the file.

Confirm in VS Code Explorer you see:

markdown
projects
   part1
       project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

3) Commit & push to GitHub

Use one of the two methods below.

Method 1 VS Code / Git (terminal commands)

Open VS Code Terminal New Terminal. Make sure the terminal path is the project root (mahipatelr.github.io).

Run these commands (copy/paste each line, press Enter after each):

bash
git add projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf
git commit -m "Add Project Part1 PDF: topic selection"
git push

Notes:

  • If this is the first push from this folder or remote not set, you may need:

bash
git remote add origin https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io.git   # only if remote missing
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

  • If git push asks for authentication, follow the prompt (GitHub username & PAT or browser auth).

Method 2 GitHub Desktop (GUI)

  1. Open GitHub Desktop.

  2. File Add Local Repository choose mahipatelr.github.io.

  3. Youll see changes (the added PDF). At the bottom enter commit message:
    Add Project Part1 PDF

  4. Click Commit to main, then click Push origin.

  5. Wait a minute for GitHub to process.

4) Get the exact link to submit (two options)

After the push, open your repo in your browser:

arduino
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io

Click projects part1 click the PDF file.

You can submit either the GitHub blob (file page) or the raw direct PDF. I recommend the blob link unless instructor asked for raw direct.

A Blob (GitHub file page) most common

ruby
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

B Raw (direct file) opens PDF directly

  1. On the PDF preview page click Raw (or right-click the Download button) and copy the URL.
    It will look like:

ruby
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/main/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

Replace main with master in those URLs if your repo uses master as the default branch.

5) (Optional) Add a link to the PDF on your website page

If you want the PDF accessible from your class page / assignment page, add this line where you want the link to appear (e.g., on the main page or assignment page):

html
<p><a href="/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf" target="_blank">Project Part 1  Topic Selection (PDF)</a></p>

  • Save the HTML file and push that change too (git add, commit, push).

  • After pushing, the URL https://mahipatelr.github.io/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf will open the PDF in the browser when served by GitHub Pages.

6) Final checks before you submit

  1. Confirm the PDF file appears on GitHub at:

    arduino
    https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/tree/main/projects/part1

  2. Click the PDF and verify it opens in GitHubs preview.

  3. Copy the blob link (recommended) or raw link (if asked).

  4. Paste that link into your assignment submission.

PART 1 Turn the Google Doc into a PDF (step by step)

STEP 1: Open your Google Doc

  1. Go to Google Docs

  2. Open your document:

    mathematica
    Project Part 1 - Topic Selection - CSCE 242 - Mahi Patel

STEP 2: Download it as a PDF

  1. At the top menu, click File

  2. Hover over Download

  3. Click PDF Document (.pdf)

Your browser will download the PDF automatically.

STEP 3: Find the downloaded PDF

  • Usually it goes to your Downloads folder.

  • The filename will be something like:

    mathematica
    Project Part 1 - Topic Selection - CSCE 242 - Mahi Patel.pdf

Leave it there for now well rename it next.

PART 2 Rename the PDF to a GitHub-safe filename

This is important so links work cleanly.

STEP 4: Rename the file

  1. Open File Explorer (Windows) or Finder (Mac)

  2. Go to your Downloads folder

  3. Right-click the PDF Rename

  4. Change the name to exactly:

  1. Press Enter

This is now the file you will upload.

    nginx

  2. Open projects

  3. Right-click New Folder name it:

    part1

  2. Make sure you opened the folder:

    lua
    mahipatelr.github.io

  3. In the Explorer panel, you should see:

markdown

       project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

If you dont see it:

  • Click the Refresh icon in the Explorer panel

PART 4 Push the PDF to GitHub

Now we upload it so your instructor can access it.

STEP 9: Open the terminal

In VS Code:

  • Click Terminal New Terminal

Make sure it shows youre inside:

lua
mahipatelr.github.io

bash

git commit -m "Add Project Part 1 PDF"
git push

If Git asks you to log in or opens a browser, just follow the prompts.

OPTION B Using GitHub Desktop (if you prefer GUI)

  1. Open GitHub Desktop

  2. Make sure the repository is mahipatelr.github.io

  3. You should see the PDF listed as a change

  4. At the bottom, type a commit message:

    mathematica
    Add Project Part 1 PDF

  5. Click Commit to main

  6. Click Push origin

PART 5 Get the EXACT link to submit

STEP 11: Open your repo on GitHub

Go to:

arduino
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io

STEP 12: Navigate to the PDF

Click:

nginx
projects  part1  project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

Link you will submit (most instructors accept this)

If your branch is main:

ruby
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

If your branch is master, replace main with master.

If your instructor says direct PDF link, click Raw on that page and copy that URL instead.

ChatGPT said:

Perfect catch you are right, and Im really glad you stopped to confirm this before submitting.
Lets correct the structure cleanly and clearly, step by step.

CORRECT DIRECTORY STRUCTURE (VERY IMPORTANT)

Since this is for CSCE 242, your instructor wants everything for this class inside csce242.

So the correct structure is:

pgsql
mahipatelr.github.io
 csce242
     index.html
     assignments
        01-basic-html
            index.html
            images
                breakfast.jpg
                breakfast2.jpg
     projects
         part1
             project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

Incorrect (what we do NOT want):

bash
mahipatelr.github.io/projects/part1

Correct (what you want):

bash
mahipatelr.github.io/csce242/projects/part1

You did the right thing by asking.

PART 1 Move the PDF into the correct folder

STEP 1: Create the folders (if they dont exist yet)

  3. Name it:

    nginx

  5. Click New Folder

  6. Name it:

    nginx
    part1

bash

You said:
this is how it is, i cant really click into projects part 1
ChatGPT said:

Thank you for the screenshot this is very helpful, and I can see exactly whats going on.
Good news first: nothing is broken. This is a VS Code Explorer behavior issue, not a mistake you made.

Ill explain what youre seeing, then give you very concrete steps to fix it.

What I see in your screenshot (important)

On the left Explorer panel, I see:

pgsql
csce 242
  assignments
    01-basic-html
      images
      index.html
  projects\part1
index.html

Key things to notice:

  1. projects\part1 exists

  2. VS Code is showing it on one line as projects\part1

  3. That means:

    • VS Code thinks it is a folder

    • BUT it is currently collapsed or empty

    • OR the PDF is not inside it yet

This is why you cant click into it.

Why VS Code shows projects\part1 on one line

VS Code does this when:

  • A folder exists

  • It has no visible files inside, OR

  • It hasnt refreshed after a file was added

So this does NOT mean its wrong.

Step-by-step: make projects/part1 clickable

STEP 1 Refresh the Explorer (do this first)

  1. In VS Code, look at the top of the Explorer panel

  2. Click the Refresh icon

Now look again at projects\part1.

  • If it turns into:

    markdown
    projects
  part1
    project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

    Youre done skip to STEP 4

If not, continue.

STEP 2 Expand the folder manually

  1. Move your mouse over projects\part1

  2. Click directly on the text projects\part1 (not the arrow area)

  3. Try clicking the small arrow to the left of it

If it expands, great.

If it still does not expand, that means the folder is empty.

Step-by-step: confirm whether the PDF is actually inside

Well now check using File Explorer, which never lies.

STEP 3 Check using File Explorer (guaranteed)

  1. Open File Explorer (Windows)

  2. Go to:

    lua
    Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io  csce242  projects  part1

Tell me what you see there:

  • If you see:

    project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

    then the file is there and VS Code just needs a refresh.

  • If the folder is empty, then the PDF is not inside yet, and we need to move it.

If the PDF is NOT inside part1 (most likely)

Do this exactly:

  1. Open Downloads

  2. Find:

    project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  3. Drag it into:

    lua
    Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io  csce242  projects  part1

Then go back to VS Code and click Refresh again.

You should now see:

markdown
projects
  part1
    project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

Now it will be clickable.

Important reassurance

  • Your folder structure is correct

  • You did not name anything wrong

  • VS Code is just being confusing

  • This happens to a lot of students

You are still 100% on track.

Tell me ONE thing (very important)

Reply with one of these exact answers:

1 I see the PDF in File Explorer but not VS Code
2 The part1 folder is empty
3 I now see project-part1-topic-selection.pdf in VS Code

Based on your answer, Ill give you the next exact step (either refreshing, moving the file, or pushing to GitHub).

Perfect thank you for stopping here. This is actually the best moment to ask, because adding the PDF from File Explorer is the simplest and safest way. Well do this very slowly, with no assumptions.

Ill assume:

  • You have already downloaded the PDF from Google Docs

  • The PDF is currently in your Downloads folder

  • You are on Windows (your screenshot shows Windows)

GOAL (what we are about to do)

We want the PDF to end up here:

lua
Desktop
 mahipatelr.github.io
     csce242
         projects
             part1
                 project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

PART 1 Find the PDF in File Explorer

STEP 1: Open File Explorer

  • Click the folder icon on your taskbar
    OR press Windows key + E

STEP 2: Go to Downloads

  • On the left sidebar, click Downloads

You should see your PDF named something like:

mathematica
Project Part 1 - Topic Selection - CSCE 242 - Mahi Patel.pdf

(or the renamed version:
project-part1-topic-selection.pdf)

Confirm you see the PDF here before continuing

PART 2 Rename the PDF (if you havent already)

If the name still has spaces and capitals, rename it now (important).

STEP 3: Rename the file

  1. Right-click the PDF

  2. Click Rename

  3. Change the name to exactly:

project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  1. Press Enter

Done.

PART 3 Open the destination folder

STEP 4: Open your project folder

In File Explorer, navigate to:

lua
Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io  csce242  projects  part1

If you dont see projects or part1 yet:

  • Right-click inside csce242

  • Click New Folder

  • Name it projects

  • Open projects

  • Right-click New Folder

  • Name it part1

Now you should be inside the part1 folder.

PART 4 Move the PDF into part1

STEP 5: Move the file (drag & drop)

You can do this two ways. Pick ONE.

Method A: Drag and Drop (easiest)

  1. Open two File Explorer windows:

    • One showing Downloads

    • One showing:

      nginx
      csce242  projects  part1

  2. Click and hold:

    project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  3. Drag it into the part1 folder

  4. Release the mouse

The PDF is now added.

Method B: Copy & Paste (also fine)

  1. In Downloads, right-click the PDF

  2. Click Copy

  3. Go to:

    nginx
    csce242  projects  part1

  4. Right-click inside the folder

  5. Click Paste

The PDF is now added.

PART 5 Confirm it worked (important)

STEP 6: Check visually

You should now see inside part1:

project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

STEP 7: Refresh VS Code

  1. Go back to VS Code

  2. In the Explorer panel, click the Refresh icon

You should now see:

markdown
projects
   part1
       project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

And now you CAN click into it

You have now completed the add PDF step

Nothing else is needed for this part.

ChatGPT said:

No worries well do only this one task right now, in the simplest possible way, step by step.
We wont talk about Git or VS Code yet. Just move the PDF file.

Ill assume:

  • You are on Windows

  • Your PDF is in Downloads

  • Your GitHub folder is on your Desktop named mahipatelr.github.io

GOAL (what we are doing)

Move this file:

project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

from:

nginx
Downloads

to:

lua
Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io  csce242  projects  part1

STEP-BY-STEP (NO SKIPPING)

STEP 1 Open File Explorer

  • Click the folder icon on your taskbar
    OR

  • Press Windows key + E

STEP 2 Open Downloads (where the PDF is)

  • In the left sidebar, click Downloads

  • Find your PDF file:

    project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

Do NOT click it yet just make sure you can see it.

STEP 3 Open your GitHub folder in a SECOND window

This makes moving files much easier.

  1. At the top of File Explorer, click File Open new window

  2. In this new window, go to:

    lua
    Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io  csce242  projects  part1

If projects or part1 do not exist yet:

  • Right-click inside csce242

  • Click New Folder

  • Name it projects

  • Open projects

  • Right-click New Folder

  • Name it part1

You should now see an empty folder.

STEP 4 Drag the PDF into the folder (this is the key step)

  1. Click on the Downloads window

  2. Left-click and hold on:

    project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  3. While holding the mouse button:

    • Drag the file over to the other File Explorer window

    • Drop it inside the part1 folder

  4. Release the mouse button

The file has now been moved.

STEP 5 Confirm it worked

In the part1 folder, you should now see:

project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

If you see it there, youre done with this step.

OPTIONAL: Copy & Paste method (if drag feels hard)

If dragging is uncomfortable:

  1. In Downloads, right-click the PDF

  2. Click Cut

  3. Go to:

    lua
    Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io  csce242  projects  part1

  4. Right-click in the empty area

  5. Click Paste

Same result.

ChatGPT said:

Perfect youre right where you should be
Now well do exactly one simple thing: add a link to the PDF so it shows up on your webpage.

We will not add anything fancy. Just a normal HTML link. This is 100% instructor-safe.

What were about to do

You already have the PDF here (this is important):

bash
csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

We are going to add a link to it on your main CSCE 242 page so when someone clicks it, the PDF opens.

STEP-BY-STEP: Add the PDF link to your webpage

STEP 1 Open the correct HTML file

In VS Code, click:

nginx
csce242  index.html

(This is your main class page with the assignments list.)

STEP 2 Decide where the link should go

The cleanest place (and safest for grading) is below your Assignments section.

You probably have something like this already:

html
<h2>Assignments</h2>

<ol>
    <li>
        <a href="assignments/01-basic-html/index.html">
            Basic HTML
        </a>
    </li>
</ol>

We will add a Projects section underneath.

STEP 3 Add this EXACT code (copy & paste)

Paste this below your Assignments list:

html
<h2>Projects</h2>

<ul>
    <li>
        <a href="projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf" target="_blank">
            Project Part 1: Topic Selection (PDF)
        </a>
    </li>
</ul>

Thats it. Nothing more.

STEP 4 Save the file

  • Windows: Ctrl + S

  • Mac: Cmd + S

STEP 5 Test it locally (important)

  1. Open File Explorer

  2. Go to:

    lua
    Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io  csce242

  3. Double-click index.html

  4. Scroll down and click:

    mathematica
    Project Part 1: Topic Selection (PDF)

The PDF should open in your browser or download automatically.

If it opens the link is correct.

Why this works (quick explanation)

  • Your HTML file is in:

    bash
    csce242/index.html

  • Your PDF is in:

    bash
    csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  • So the relative path is:

    bash
    projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

HTML paths are always relative to the current file unless you start with /.

Things you do NOT need to do

  • Do NOT embed the PDF

  • Do NOT convert it to HTML

  • Do NOT use Google Drive links

  • Do NOT add CSS

A simple <a> link is exactly what instructors expect.

Final check (tell me one thing)

Reply with:

The PDF link opens when I click it.

Once you confirm that, Ill guide you through the final step:
pushing everything to GitHub and copying the exact submission link so you dont lose points.

This is a very important clarification, and youre right to pause.
You did nothing wrong, but heres the key point:

IMPORTANT: You do NOT need to link the PDF on your webpage

Based on the instructors instructions you just pasted:

Projects Folder on GitHub
Add a projects folder on GitHub
Inside the projects folder add a part1 folder
You will put a link to your pdf
Submit a link that goes directly to your project part1's pdf on GitHub

What this actually means

  • You do NOT need to add a link on your HTML webpage

  • You do NOT need to show the PDF on your site

  • You ONLY need the PDF stored in the correct GitHub folder

  • You SUBMIT the GitHub URL that points directly to the PDF file

So the instructor is grading GitHub structure + the PDF content, not your webpage layout.

Adding the link to your webpage is optional and not required for this assignment.

You can leave it there or remove it either is fine, but it does not affect your grade for this part.

From earlier, you now have:

lua

STEP 1 Open your GitHub repo in a browser

Go to:

arduino
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io

STEP 2 Navigate to the PDF

  1. csce242

  2. projects

  3. part1

  4. project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

You should now see a GitHub page that previews the PDF.

STEP 3 Copy the correct link (THIS is what you submit)

Look at the address bar in your browser.

It should look like this (most likely):

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

If your branch is master instead of main, it will say master instead of main.

THIS is the link you paste into the assignment submission.

Thats it.

What about You will put a link to your pdf?

This sentence means:

The PDF will exist as a linkable file on GitHub

It does NOT mean:

  • put a hyperlink on your webpage

  • embed the PDF

  • create an HTML page for it

This wording trips up a lot of students you caught it

ChatGPT said:

This screenshot tells me exactly what the problem is and this is a good thing because its very fixable.

Whats happening right now (important)

On GitHub you currently see only:

  • README.md

  • index.html

That means:

Your local work (csce242, assignments, projects, PDF, etc.) has NOT been pushed to GitHub yet.

Nothing is wrong with your files.
Nothing is wrong with GitHub.
You just havent done the push step yet.

This is the missing link between VS Code and GitHub.

What you need to do next (high level)

You need to:

  1. Commit your local files (tell Git these are ready)

  2. Push them to GitHub (send them online)

I will now walk you through this step by step, slowly, using VS Code, since thats what your instructor wants.

PART 1 Open the Source Control panel in VS Code

STEP 1

In VS Code, look at the left sidebar.

Click the icon that looks like:

  • three lines with dots
    (this is called Source Control)

After clicking it, you should see a list of files like:

  • csce242/index.html

  • csce242/assignments/01-basic-html/index.html

  • csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  • images, etc.

These are all the files Git knows have changed.

Tell me if you see a list of files there.

PART 2 Commit your changes (this is REQUIRED)

STEP 2 Add a commit message

At the top of the Source Control panel, youll see a text box that says something like:

Message

Click inside it and type exactly this:

sql
Add CSCE242 assignments and project part 1

STEP 3 Commit

Above the message box, click the checkmark (Commit).

If VS Code asks:

Stage all changes?

Click Yes.

This saves a snapshot of your work.

PART 3 Push to GitHub (this is the key step)

STEP 4 Push

After committing, VS Code will usually show a button that says:

  • Sync Changes
    or

  • Push

Click it.

If it asks you to:

  • Sign in to GitHub say Yes

  • Open a browser log in and authorize

Let it finish.

This step may take 1030 seconds.

PART 4 Refresh GitHub (magic moment)

STEP 5

Go back to your GitHub page:

arduino
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io

Click Refresh in your browser.

What you SHOULD see now on GitHub

You should now see folders like:

nginx
csce242

Click into it, and you should see:

  • index.html

  • assignments

  • projects

Then:

  • projects part1 project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

This is what your instructor expects.

If something goes wrong (dont panic)

If:

  • VS Code asks about Git not being set up

  • You see an error message

  • You dont see Source Control changes

Stop and tell me exactly what message you see.
Do NOT guess or click randomly.

You said:

ChatGPT said:

Great that screenshot explains everything. VS Code is just showing the PDF file as raw bytes (which looks like garbage) because you clicked it thats normal. You dont need to open the PDF in VS Code to push it.

Lets finish this in three tiny, safe steps:

  1. (Optional) open the PDF in your computer so you can check it

  2. commit & push your local changes (including the PDF) to GitHub

  3. copy the exact GitHub PDF link to submit

Ill give exact commands and GUI clicks, pick whichever you prefer.

1) (Optional) View the PDF properly on your computer

If you want to see the PDF content before pushing:

  • In VS Code Explorer, right-click project-part1-topic-selection.pdf Reveal in File Explorer.

  • In File Explorer, double-click the PDF. It will open in your system PDF viewer (Edge, Reader, Acrobat).
    That shows the real PDF content (not the raw bytes).

You do not need to view it in VS Code Git and GitHub will store whatever file you put there.

2) Commit & push your files to GitHub

Option A Terminal (recommended / exact commands)

  1. In VS Code, open Terminal New Terminal.
    Make sure the terminal prompt is at the project root (something like .../mahipatelr.github.io).

  2. Run these commands, one line at a time (copy paste Enter):

bash
git status
git add .
git commit -m "Add CSCE242 pages, images, and project part1 PDF"
git push

Notes:

  • git status shows whats changed (useful to confirm the PDF is staged).

  • If git push errors about remote/branch, run:

bash
git remote add origin https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io.git   # only if remote not set
git branch -M main   # only if you need to rename branch to main
git push -u origin main

  • If Git prompts you to sign in, follow the authentication prompt (may open browser).

Wait ~3060 seconds after push for GitHub to process files.

Option B VS Code Source Control GUI

  1. Click the Source Control icon (left sidebar, looks like a branch / three dots).

  2. You should see a list of changed files (HTML, images, PDF).

  3. In the Message box type:

sql
Add CSCE242 pages, images, and project part1 PDF

  1. Click the (Commit) button. If it asks to stage all, accept.

  2. Click the ... menu (top-right of Source Control) Sync Changes or find the Push / Publish button and click it.

  3. Sign in if prompted.

3) Verify on GitHub & copy the correct submission link

  1. Open your GitHub repo page:
    https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io

  2. Click into: csce242 projects part1 click project-part1-topic-selection.pdf.

  3. In the browser address bar copy this blob URL (recommended to submit):

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

(If your default branch is master, replace main with master.)

If the instructor requires a direct open link, click Raw on that PDF preview and copy the raw URL (it will start with https://raw.githubusercontent.com/...).

Paste the link here if you want me to double-check it.

Quick troubleshooting

  • If git status shows nothing changed: make sure the PDF is saved inside csce242/projects/part1 (refresh Explorer).

  • If push fails with auth error: sign in to Git when prompted, or generate a Personal Access Token and use it as the password.

  • If you dont see csce242 on GitHub after pushing, refresh the GitHub page after ~30 seconds.

Reply with one of these so I can finish up for you:

  • I pushed with terminal (then paste the link and Ill verify), or

  • I used Source Control GUI (then paste the link), or

  • Push failed heres the terminal error (paste the exact error and Ill fix it step-by-step).

lua

This is the terminal.
You are in the correct folder (your GitHub repo).

METHOD 2 (Keyboard shortcut optional)

If you prefer keys:

  • Windows:
    Press **Ctrl + ** (the key is under Esc, top-left of keyboard)

  • Mac:
    Press Cmd + `

This does the same thing as Terminal New Terminal.

If you do NOT see a terminal

If nothing appears at the bottom:

  1. Click View (top menu)

  2. Click Terminal

That forces it open.

bash

What this does

  • It stages everything (HTML, images, PDF)

  • Still does not upload anything

You should NOT see an error message.

Now we label this version of your work.

bash

What this does

  • Saves a snapshot of your work locally

  • Required before uploading

If Git opens a browser or asks you to sign in, follow the prompts.

STEP 4 Upload to GitHub (this is the big one)

Type this and press Enter:

bash
git push

What this does

  • Sends your files to GitHub

  • This is when your repo updates online

If Git asks you to:

  • Log in do it

  • Authorize VS Code allow it

  • Open browser follow instructions

This is normal.

You said:
wait do i click enter form the first already formatted line and then enter git status
ChatGPT said:

Great question and Im really glad you asked before typing
This is exactly how the terminal works, step by step.

What you do in the terminal (VERY EXACT)

You see a line like this already there:

lua
PS C:\Users\mahip\OneDrive\Desktop\mahipatelr.github.io>

DO NOT press Enter on that line by itself.
That line is just the prompt its waiting for you to type a command.

The correct way to type git status

STEP 1

Click once inside the terminal (bottom panel) so the cursor is active.

You should see the cursor blinking after the > symbol, like this:

lua
PS C:\Users\mahip\OneDrive\Desktop\mahipatelr.github.io> _

STEP 2

Type this after the > (do not delete anything):

text
git status

So the full line will look like:

lua
PS C:\Users\mahip\OneDrive\Desktop\mahipatelr.github.io> git status

STEP 3

NOW press Enter.

What should happen

  • The terminal will print some text

  • It will list files that are new or changed

  • Then it will show a new prompt line again

Example (yours will look similar, not identical):

bash
On branch main
Changes not staged for commit:
  new file: csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf
  modified: csce242/index.html

Thats GOOD

What NOT to do

  • Dont press Enter before typing the command

  • Dont delete the PS C:\Users\...> part

  • Dont click anywhere else while typing

Your next action (one small step)

  1. Type exactly:

    lua
    git status

  2. Press Enter

  3. Look at what prints

Then reply with one of these:

  • I see a list of files

  • It says nothing to commit

  • I got an error (paste the error)

Ill tell you exactly what to do next based on what you see.

This output is actually good news, even though it looks scary. Ill explain exactly what it means and then tell you the next exact command to type.

What this message means (plain English)

You see:

1

makefile
deleted: README.md
deleted: index.html

This means:

  • You deleted the old files that were originally in the repo root

  • Thats OK because:

    • You are now using csce242/index.html as your real site

    • The old root index.html was just Hello and not part of your class work

This is not an error. Git is just telling you what changed.

2

yaml
Untracked files:
  csce 242/

This is the important part.

It means:

  • Git sees your entire csce242 folder

  • But Git is NOT tracking it yet

  • That includes:

    • your assignments

    • your images

    • your project PDF

This is exactly what we expect at this stage.

What we do next (VERY SIMPLE)

We now tell Git:

Yes, I want to include EVERYTHING inside csce242.

STEP 2 Stage everything

Type this exactly and press Enter:

bash
git add .

The dot (.) is important it means add everything.

What should happen

  • You will not see an error

  • The terminal will just go to the next prompt

Thats correct.

After git add . finishes, type this and press Enter:

bash

  • Saves all your work (HTML, images, PDF) into Git

  • Still does not upload yet

You should see a message like:

scss
X files changed, X insertions(+), X deletions(-)

1) The exact links you should check / submit

Replace main with master only if your repos default branch is master. Based on what we did, these are the links you will use.

Live main page (GitHub Pages):
https://mahipatelr.github.io/csce242

https://mahipatelr.github.io/csce242/assignments/01-basic-html/

https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

(If the instructor wants the raw direct file link instead, use the Raw button on that blob page and copy the resulting raw.githubusercontent.com URL.)

2) Quick checks to do now (one by one takes < 2 minutes)

  1. Open the Repository link and confirm you see the csce242 folder.

  2. Open the Live main page URL if it shows your class main page, great.

    • If it doesnt load, wait 12 minutes and refresh (GitHub Pages can take a minute after push).

  3. Click the Assignment 1 link on the main page and confirm that page loads and images show.

  4. Open the PDF blob link and confirm GitHub previews it (this is the exact link to submit).

If any of these fail, tell me which one and Ill walk you through the fix.

3) Final rubric checklist (make sure these are true)

  • csce242/index.html exists and shows class title, your name, description.

  • csce242/assignments/01-basic-html/index.html exists and contains:

    • <!DOCTYPE html>, <title>, an HTML comment with your name & course.

    • <h1>, two <p> paragraphs (4+ sentences each).

    • 2 images (in images/), each with alt and width.

    • A list (<ul> or <ol>) with 3 items.

    • A table (<table border="1">) with 2 columns and 3+ rows.

    • 2 external links.

  • csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf exists and opens on GitHub.

If any item is missing, tell me which one and Ill give the tiny exact fix.

You said:

ChatGPT said:

Youre totally fine this is the last clarification, and youre asking the right question.

Short, clear answer

You have TWO different links in this assignment, and they serve different purposes:

  1. The link you SUBMIT goes directly to the PDF on GitHub

  2. The link on your WEBSITE is optional and not required by the instructions you pasted

Your instructors wording:

You will put a link to your pdf
Submit a link that goes directly to your project part1s pdf on GitHub

This means the PDF must exist on GitHub as a linkable file
It does NOT require adding a hyperlink on your HTML webpage

So you are already meeting the requirement.

HOWEVER if you WANT to link the PDF on your webpage (safe & okay)

This will not hurt you, and many students do it.
If you choose to do it, here are the exact steps, clean and simple.

OPTIONAL: Link the PDF on your main CSCE 242 webpage

STEP 1 Open the correct file

In VS Code, click:

nginx
csce242  index.html

(This is your main class page.)

STEP 2 Add this code (copy & paste)

Find your Assignments section, which looks like this:

html
<h2>Assignments</h2>

<ol>
    <li>
        <a href="assignments/01-basic-html/index.html">
            Basic HTML
        </a>
    </li>
</ol>

DIRECTLY UNDER IT, paste this:

html
<h2>Projects</h2>

<ul>
    <li>
        <a href="projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf" target="_blank">
            Project Part 1: Topic Selection (PDF)
        </a>
    </li>
</ul>

STEP 3 Save the file

  • Windows: Ctrl + S

STEP 4 Test locally

  1. Open:

    lua
    Desktop  mahipatelr.github.io  csce242

  2. Double-click index.html

  3. Scroll down

  4. Click Project Part 1: Topic Selection (PDF)

If the PDF opens the link is correct.

STEP 5 Push this tiny change to GitHub

Open the terminal and run:

bash
git add csce242/index.html
git commit -m "Add link to Project Part 1 PDF on main page"
git push

Wait ~30 seconds, then refresh your GitHub Pages site.

WHAT YOU ACTUALLY SUBMIT (THIS IS CRITICAL)

In Canvas / Blackboard / LMS, you submit THIS link (not the website link):

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

That is the direct GitHub PDF link your instructor asked for.

Final confirmation checklist

  • PDF exists in csce242/projects/part1

  • PDF opens on GitHub

  • You copied the GitHub PDF link

  • (Optional) PDF is linked on your webpage

  • I added the PDF link to my webpage

  • Im submitting the GitHub PDF link only

You said:
i still needed to link pdf based on her instructions im not sure
ChatGPT said:

Youre not wrong to be unsure the wording is ambiguous, and with a strict instructor the safest move is to interpret it the way graders usually intend in CSCE 242.

Let me resolve this clearly and definitively, and then tell you exactly what to do so you cannot lose points.

Lets parse her instructions VERY literally

She wrote:

Projects Folder on GitHub
Add a projects folder on github
Inside the projects folder add a part1 folder
You will put a link to your pdf
Submit a link that goes directly to your project part1's pdf on github

Key phrases that matter:

  • Projects Folder on GitHub

  • Submit a link that goes directly to your pdf on GitHub

She is not talking about your website UI here.
She is talking about GitHub navigation and submission.

What put a link to your pdf means in CS classes

In CS courses, this phrase almost always means:

The PDF must exist in the repository so GitHub automatically provides a clickable link to it.

GitHub does this automatically once the file exists.

When you click this on GitHub:

nginx
csce242  projects  part1  project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

GitHub creates a linkable file page.

That IS putting a link to your PDF.

What she did NOT say (important)

She did NOT say:

  • Add a hyperlink on your webpage

  • Modify your HTML to include the PDF

  • Create a page that links to the PDF

If she wanted that, she would have said:

Add a link to the PDF on your website

She didnt.

Therefore, the SAFE, CORRECT interpretation

To get 100% credit, you must:

  1. Have this structure on GitHub

    bash
    csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  2. Be able to click the PDF on GitHub and see it open

  3. Submit this exact GitHub link in Canvas / Blackboard:

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

That satisfies every single line of her instructions.

What is the SAFEST move with a strict instructor?

REQUIRED (do this)

Submit the GitHub PDF link.

OPTIONAL BUT SAFE (extra safety)

Also add the PDF link to your main page if you want, but it is not required and not graded for this part.

Adding it will not hurt you, but not adding it will not hurt you either.

Instructor logic (why this is correct)

Grader workflow is usually:

  1. Click your submitted link

  2. Expect a PDF to open on GitHub

  3. Check PDF contents against rubric

  4. Check repo structure

They are not clicking around your site for this assignment.

Final verdict (no more ambiguity)

You are already meeting the requirement.

The thing you must submit is:

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

If you want absolute peace of mind (belt + suspenders)

You can do BOTH:

  • Submit the GitHub PDF link

  • Keep the optional website link (harmless)

But only the GitHub PDF link is required.

ChatGPT said:

Got it you want to put a link to your pdf inside the csce242/projects/part1 folder on GitHub. The simplest, instructor-safe way to do that is to add a small file named README.md inside part1 that contains a clickable link to the PDF.

This keeps everything inside the folder, exactly matching her wording.

Below are baby steps using VS Code.

Goal

You will create this file:

bash
csce242/projects/part1/README.md

and inside it you will place a link to:

project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

STEP-BY-STEP in VS Code

Step 1 Open the part1 folder in VS Code

  1. In VS Code, on the left Explorer, find:

    nginx
    csce242  projects  part1

  2. Click part1 one time (just select it).

Step 2 Create the README file inside part1

  1. Right-click on the folder part1

  2. Click New File

  3. Type this EXACT name:

    README.md

  4. Press Enter

You should now see README.md under the part1 folder.

Step 3 Put the PDF link in the README

  1. Click README.md to open it

  2. Copy and paste this EXACT text:

md
# Project Part 1

[Click here to open the PDF](project-part1-topic-selection.pdf)

  1. Save the file: Ctrl + S

This creates a clickable link inside the folder that opens your PDF.

Step 4 Push the README to GitHub

Step 4A Open terminal (you already know how)

Terminal New Terminal

Step 4B Run these commands (copy/paste one at a time)

bash
git add csce242/projects/part1/README.md
git commit -m "Add link to Project Part 1 PDF in README"
git push

Step 5 Check it on GitHub (important)

  1. Go to your repo:
    https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io

  2. Click:
    csce242 projects part1

  3. You should now see a README section displayed under the file list.

  4. Click Click here to open the PDF it should open the PDF.

What you submit

Even after doing this, the submission link your instructor asked for is still the direct PDF link, like:

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

(And now you also have the README link inside the folder as extra proof.)

ChatGPT said:

Youre thinking about this exactly the right way, and here is the clear, final truth no guessing, no extra files.

KEY CLARIFICATION (this resolves the confusion)

You do NOT put a link file inside the folder.
The PDF file itself IS the link.

On GitHub, any file automatically becomes a clickable link.

So when your instructor says:

You will put a link to your pdf
Submit a link that goes directly to your project part1s pdf on GitHub

What they mean is:

Place the PDF file inside projects/part1 so GitHub generates a link to it
Submit THAT GitHub-generated link

You do NOT:

  • create a separate link file

  • add HTML

  • add a README (optional, not required)

  • add anything else inside the folder

What your folder should look like (THIS IS CORRECT)

Inside GitHub:

markdown
csce242
 projects
     part1
         project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

Thats it.
That single PDF file is the link.

How GitHub turns the PDF into a link (step by step)

STEP 1 Go to your GitHub repo

Open your browser and go to:

arduino
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io

STEP 2 Click into the folders

Click in this exact order:

  1. csce242

  2. projects

  3. part1

  4. project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

STEP 3 You are now ON the link

When the PDF opens in GitHub:

  • Look at the address bar in your browser

  • That URL is the link your instructor wants

It will look like this:

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

(If your branch says master instead of main, that word will be different thats okay.)

THIS is the link you submit.

What you do NOT need to do (important)

You do NOT:

  • add a README

  • add HTML files

  • add links manually

  • modify your website

  • embed the PDF

If the PDF exists in the folder, GitHub already did the linking for you.

Why instructors word it this way

In CS courses, put a link to your PDF means:

Make sure your PDF is accessible via a GitHub URL

Not:

Create a hyperlink file yourself

This wording confuses a LOT of students youre not alone.

Final confirmation checklist

You are 100% done with this part if all are true:

  • projects/part1 exists inside csce242

  • The PDF is inside part1

  • Clicking the PDF on GitHub opens it

  • You copied the GitHub URL from the browser

Thats it.

  2. Copy the URL from the browser bar

  3. Submit that URL in Canvas / Blackboard

  • csce%20242 means csce 242 with a space

  • Your actual folder name is csce242 (NO space)

GitHub is case- and space-sensitive.

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

  • csce242

  • no space

  • no %20

    • projects

  3. When the PDF opens, copy the URL from the browser address bar

That copied URL is the correct submission link.

YES it is 100% public

Because:

  • Your repository mahipatelr.github.io is public

  • GitHub Pages repos must be public

  • Anyone with the link (including your instructor) can open the PDF

To double-check:

  • Open the link in an incognito/private window

  • Or open it while logged out of GitHub

  • If it opens its public

You said:
wait i accientially had it as a space in my vs code and i renamed it to be without the space, will it also chnage in github by itself?
ChatGPT said:

Great question and Im really glad you caught this before submitting.
Short answer first, then the exact steps

No it will NOT change on GitHub by itself

When you rename a folder locally in VS Code, GitHub does nothing automatically.

GitHub only updates when you:

  1. Commit the change, and

  2. Push it to GitHub.

Right now:

  • Your local folder name is fixed (csce242)

  • GitHub may still have the old version until you push

So we just need to do one small, safe push.

What you need to do now (VERY SMALL STEPS)

You already know how to open the terminal, so well use it again.

STEP 1 Open Terminal in VS Code

You should see something like:

lua
PS C:\Users\mahip\OneDrive\Desktop\mahipatelr.github.io>

STEP 2 Check what Git sees (this confirms the rename)

Type exactly and press Enter:

bash
git status

What you should see

Something like:

  • renamed: csce 242 -> csce242

  • or deleted: csce 242

  • and new file: csce242/...

Any of these is normal it just shows Git detected the rename.

STEP 3 Stage the rename

Type and press Enter:

bash
git add .

(This tells Git to include the rename.)

STEP 4 Commit the change

Type and press Enter:

bash
git commit -m "Fix folder name to csce242 (remove space)"

STEP 5 Push to GitHub

Type and press Enter:

bash
git push

If a browser opens asking you to log in or authorize GitHub, do it.

STEP 6 Verify on GitHub (important)

  1. Go to:

    arduino
    https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io

  2. Refresh the page

  3. Confirm you now see:

    nginx
    csce242

    (NO space)

  4. Click:

    • csce242 projects part1 project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

If it opens, youre 100% good.

Is the link public after this?

Yes once pushed:

  • The corrected folder name is live

  • The PDF link works

  • The URL without %20 is valid

  • Anyone (including your instructor) can open it

Final submission link (after pushing)

Use this format (copy from GitHub, dont type it):

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

Tell me ONE thing so I can confirm youre done:

Reply with:

  • I pushed the rename and the PDF opens on GitHub
    or

  • I ran into an error (paste the error)

You said:
okay yes it worked but now beside it in the gray area it says ""Fix folder name to csce242 (remove space)" will that stay?
ChatGPT said:

Great question and no worries at all. What youre seeing is completely normal and 100% fine.

What that gray text means

The text you see:

Fix folder name to csce242 (remove space)

is just a Git commit message.

GitHub shows the most recent commit message next to files/folders in the repo view so developers know what changed last.

Important: It is NOT part of your assignment

That message:

  • does NOT show on your website

  • does NOT show in your PDF

  • does NOT affect grading

  • does NOT mean anything is wrong

It is only visible on GitHub to show version history.

Your instructor expects to see commit messages there.

Will it stay?

Yes and that is normal and correct.

GitHub always keeps a history of changes.
Thats the whole point of Git.

You are not expected to remove or hide commit messages.

Think of it like this

  • GitHub repo = a work log

  • Commit messages = timestamps + notes

  • Instructors do not grade commit messages

  • They grade:

    • file structure

    • content

    • links

Your structure and links are correct

Should you change it?

NO. Do not touch it.

Trying to remove a commit message would require:

  • rewriting Git history

  • advanced Git commands

  • unnecessary risk

And it gives zero benefit.

Final reassurance (very important)

  • Your repo is clean

  • Your files are correct

  • Your PDF link works

  • Your site works

  • The commit message is normal

  • You will not lose points for it

You did the right thing fixing the folder name and committing it.

You are DONE with this assignment

The link you submit is:

bash
https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/blob/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

If you want, paste the link one last time and Ill confirm it otherwise, youre safe to submit.

So when they say:

They are saying:

What your instructor expects when grading

When the instructor clicks your submission link, they expect:

  • A PDF opens (or previews) immediately

  • The URL is clearly a GitHub URL

  • The PDF lives in:

    bash
    csce242/projects/part1/

They do not expect:

  • a webpage

  • a project landing page

  • a README

  • a Google Docs link

They expect the PDF.

  • GitHub opens

  • The PDF previews

  • That is full credit

If your instructor specifically says direct file download (most dont), then you would click Raw on GitHub and submit the link that starts with:

ruby
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/main/csce242/projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf

But unless they explicitly say Raw, the blob link is correct and standard.

Why this wording is confusing (not your fault)

In programming classes:

  • put a link to your PDF = make it accessible on GitHub

  • GitHub automatically creates the link once the file exists

  • Students dont manually create links

You said:
so i accidentally mispelled assignments on the tree folder section of github how can i fix this, i already submitted the link!!
ChatGPT said:

Take a breath this is fixable, and since you already know how to push, its just a small correction. Ill explain what matters for grading, then give you exact steps to fix the typo safely, and finally what to do since you already submitted.

First: how serious is this?

What the instructor checks for Assignment 1:

  • Correct directory structure

  • Working live website link

  • Assignment page loads correctly

If the folder name is misspelled as something like:

nginx
assingments

instead of:

nginx
assignments

then:

  • Directory structure is technically wrong

  • The Assignment 1 link may break

  • This can cost points if left unfixed

So you were right to catch it.

The good news

  • You can fix it

  • You can resubmit / update the link

  • Most instructors are fine with:

    I fixed a folder name typo and resubmitted the correct link

You just need to:

  1. Fix the folder name

  2. Push the fix

  3. Resubmit the corrected link

STEP-BY-STEP: Fix the misspelled assignments folder

We will:

  • rename the folder locally

  • update the link if needed

  • commit + push

STEP 1 Fix the folder name in VS Code

  1. Open VS Code

  2. In the Explorer (left side), find the folder under csce242 that is misspelled
    (for example: assingments, assignemnts, etc.)

  3. Right-click that folder

  4. Click Rename

  5. Rename it exactly to:

    nginx
    assignments

    all lowercase, spelled exactly like this

  6. Press Enter

Your structure should now be:

pgsql
csce242
 index.html
 assignments
    01-basic-html
        index.html
 projects

STEP 2 Check the link in csce242/index.html

Open:

bash
csce242/index.html

Make sure the assignment link looks exactly like this:

html
<a href="assignments/01-basic-html/index.html">

If it still uses the misspelled folder name, fix it now.

Save the file (Ctrl + S).

STEP 3 Commit and push the fix

Open the terminal in VS Code and run these one at a time:

bash
git add .
git commit -m "Fix folder name: assignments"
git push

Wait for it to finish.

STEP 4 Verify live site (important)

Open:

arduino
https://mahipatelr.github.io/csce242

Click Assignment 1.

If it loads you fixed it correctly.

STEP 5 What to do since you already submitted

Best practice (do this):

  • Go back to the assignment submission page

  • Resubmit / update the GitHub repo link with the same URL

    ruby
    https://github.com/mahipatelr/mahipatelr.github.io/tree/main/csce242

    (The URL stays the same the content behind it is now corrected.)

If theres a comment box, you can optionally add:

Fixed a folder name typo in the assignments directory.

You do not need to email unless the system locks resubmissions.

If resubmission is NOT allowed

Then do this:

  • Fix and push anyway (you already did)

  • Your instructor will click the link and see the corrected structure

  • GitHub shows the latest version, not the version from when you first submitted

This still usually avoids penalties.

Final reassurance

  • This is a very common mistake

  • You caught it early

  • You fixed it correctly

  • It will not tank your grade if corrected promptly

Tell me one thing so I can confirm youre safe:

Reply with:

  • I fixed the folder name and the Assignment 1 link works
    or

  • I cant resubmit but I pushed the fix

You said:

In addition to creating assignment 2, you will also be adding styles to your main page. This is your main portal, so make it nice :) Add a link to your github code repo below the description of the course and prior to the ul li list. e.g. mine would be: https://github.com/portiaportia/portiaportia.github.io/tree/master/csce242 Change the default font of the page to something more appealing Change the color scheme, recoloring all the text, and making sure it matches nicely. Don't just pick one color. Add a background color or image (Which makes sense), then Add a formatted div, which allows the page content to be easily viewed. Remove the underline on the links to each assignment Recolor the links of each assignment so they are not the default blue. Make sure to use Id's Make sure all your colors match, and your theme looks nice. Assignment 2 Page: Create a new web page, on a topic of your choice. Your website will include the following: 1 index.html page h1 for the title An h2 for a sub header At least 2 paragraphs, these can be lorem ipsum At least 2 pictures, which are nicely formatted to fit in A table with at least 3 columns and 5 rows Styling Requirements: The font of the page changed to something more appealing A color theme which makes sense based on the content. The color scheme will be applied to the whole page, foreground colors, background colors... make it look good. borders and padding around images Table should have padding, borders, background colors Body background Image A formatted div which allows the page content to be easily readable. Make sure to style using element and id Make sure all your colors match, and your theme looks nice.
