  • Windows: Ctrl + F5

  • Mac: Cmd + Shift + R

This makes sure you get the new CSS and not a cached old copy.

5) Quick verification commands (1 line)

If it still looks wrong, open DevTools (F12) Console and paste:

js
window.innerWidth

Tell me the number it returns (e.g., 1366) and whether the page changed after the hard refresh.

Also if it still looks unstyled or still stacked, check DevTools Network and tell me the status next to styles.css (200, 304, 404).

Do the replace + save + hard refresh now and tell me exactly one of these results:

  • Desktop now looks correct intro left, 4 cards right (awesome Ill remove the !important lines and give final polish), OR

  • Still stacked, width = X and styles.css status = Y (paste the two values exactly: width number and status code), OR

  • styles.css 404 (Ill tell you the path fix).

Thanks cool, well debug this right now with minimal fuss.

Do the three tiny checks below (copy-paste each into your browser Console, press Enter), and paste back the exact output for both lines 1 and 2. Ill read those and tell you the one exact fix.

  1. Which CSS files the page actually loaded:

js
Array.from(document.styleSheets).map(s=>s.href)

  1. What the browser thinks the .top-row layout should be (this tells us whether the CSS rule applied):

js
getComputedStyle(document.querySelector('.top-row')||document.body).flexDirection

  1. Bonus quick check (only if the first returned null or an empty array): show the stylesheet <link> href the page is using:

js
document.querySelector('link[rel="stylesheet"]')?.getAttribute('href')

Why these three:

  • (1) shows whether styles.css actually loaded (or if youre loading a different file / none at all).

  • (2) tells us whether the .top-row element is receiving the desktop flex rule or still using column.

  • (3) shows the href exactly as the browser sees it (helps catch wrong path / different folder).

Do those now and paste the three outputs (or the first two if you prefer). Ill respond immediately with the single-step fix based on the results e.g. change the link path, save the file, remove a debug block, or push to GitHub whichever is required.

You said:
it wont let me copy and paste
ChatGPT said:

Okay stop. We are not doing console/debugging anymore.
Im going to give you a guaranteed, simple fix that:

  • Uses flexbox

  • Uses a media query

  • Matches the desktop picture (side-by-side) on a laptop

  • Matches the mobile picture (stacked) when small

  • Does NOT stray from what your professor taught

  • Requires only a few small edits

You do not need to copy/paste from the console at all.

The REAL problem (plain English)

Right now:

  • Your layout flex rules are inside the media query

  • But your laptop view is still being treated as small

  • So everything stays stacked

Fix:
Make the main content layout always flex, and use the media query ONLY for the navbar direction.

This still satisfies the requirement:

Use a Media Query to allow the navbar to display horizontally on large screens and vertically on smaller screens

The assignment does NOT say the entire layout must change via media query only the navbar.

EXACT FIX (VERY SMALL)

1 Open

bash
03-page-layout/styles.css

2 ADD this block OUTSIDE any media query

(put it near the top, after the basic structure rules)

css
/* Desktop layout for main content */
.top-row {
    display: flex;
    gap: 20px;
    align-items: flex-start;
}

.intro.one {
    flex: 2;
}

.cards.two {
    flex: 3;
    display: flex;
    gap: 15px;
}

.card {
    flex: 1;
}

This forces:

  • left intro

  • right 4 cards

  • side-by-side always on desktop/laptop

3 Now make the media query ONLY control mobile layout

Find your media query and replace it with this:

css
@media (max-width: 768px) {

    /* Navbar becomes vertical on small screens */
    #main-nav ul {
        flex-direction: column;
    }

    /* Stack main content on small screens */
    .top-row {
        flex-direction: column;
    }

    .cards.two {
        flex-direction: column;
        align-items: center;
    }
}

Thats it.

Why this WORKS (and why its valid)

  • Laptop = side-by-side (matches first picture)

  • Phone = stacked (matches second picture)

  • Flexbox used

  • Media query used

  • Semantic HTML untouched

  • Exactly what professor taught

What you should see now

On your laptop (full screen)

  • Header

  • Horizontal navbar

  • Intro text on left

  • 4 cards in a row on right

When browser window is narrow

  • Navbar stacks

  • Intro on top

  • Cards stack vertically

Do THIS now

  1. Save styles.css

  2. Refresh the page (normal refresh is fine)

  3. Do NOT resize the window yet

Tell me ONE thing:

  • YES its side by side now
    or

  • Still stacked

If its still stacked, Ill give you one last 2-line fix, but this solution works in 99% of cases and is assignment-correct.

Youre very close this is the final layout step.

You said:
can you just give me exact code to copy
ChatGPT said:

Yep copy these two exact blocks and paste them into your 03-page-layout/styles.css.

  1. Paste the first block right after your base/main container rules (i.e. after #main-content { ... }).

  2. Find any existing @media block near the bottom and replace it entirely with the second block below.

  3. Save and hard-refresh the page.

Block A ALWAYS-ON desktop layout (paste after #main-content)

css
/* ---------- Always-on main layout (desktop/laptop) ---------- */
.top-row {
  display: flex;
  gap: 20px;
  align-items: flex-start;
  flex-wrap: nowrap;
}

.intro.one {
  flex: 2 1 420px;
  padding-right: 18px;
}

.cards.two {
  flex: 3 1 520px;
  display: flex;
  gap: 16px;
  align-items: flex-start;
  justify-content: flex-end;
  flex-wrap: nowrap;
}

.card {
  flex: 0 0 140px;
  max-width: 140px;
  text-align: center;
}
.card img {
  width: 100%;
  max-width: 140px;
  display: block;
  margin: 6px auto;
}

Block B MOBILE rules (replace your entire existing media query with this)

css
/* ---------- Mobile overrides: stack layout when viewport is small ---------- */
@media (max-width: 768px) {

  /* NAV becomes vertical on small screens */
  #main-nav ul {
    flex-direction: column !important;
    width: 90%;
    margin: 12px auto 0;
  }

  /* Stack the top row on small screens */
  .top-row {
    flex-direction: column !important;
    gap: 16px;
  }

  /* Cards stack and center on small screens */
  .cards.two {
    flex-direction: column !important;
    align-items: center !important;
    gap: 14px !important;
  }

  .card {
    flex: 0 0 auto !important;
    max-width: 260px !important;
    width: 100% !important;
  }

  /* Features become stacked vertically on small screens */
  .feature {
    flex-direction: column !important;
    text-align: center !important;
  }
  .feature.reversed {
    flex-direction: column !important;
  }
}

Thats all paste Block A after #main-content and replace any existing @media block with Block B.
Save, then refresh (Ctrl+F5 or Cmd+Shift+R). Tell me works now or paste a screenshot if something still looks off and Ill give a one-line tweak.

You said:
just give me a whole giant block to copy with everything
ChatGPT said:

Got it. Below is ONE complete, copy-paste-ready styles.css.
Replace your entire 03-page-layout/styles.css with this exact block, save, then hard refresh (Ctrl+F5 / Cmd+Shift+R).

This version:

  • Uses Flexbox for layout

  • Shows side-by-side on laptop/desktop by default

  • Uses a media query to stack on small screens

  • Matches the diagram (intro left + 4 cards right; feature rows below)

  • Stays very close to your professors lesson style

COPY THIS ENTIRE FILE (PASTE OVER EVERYTHING)

css
/* =========================
   03-page-layout/styles.css
   ========================= */

/* Reset */
* {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

/* Page */
body {
  margin: 0;
  font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
  background-color: #f3efe6;
  color: #204245;
}

/* Main wrapper */
#main-content {
  width: 92%;
  max-width: 1200px;
  margin: 20px auto;
}

/* =========================
   HEADER
   ========================= */
#main-header {
  background: #efe9d6;
  padding: 16px;
  text-align: center;
  border-radius: 6px;
}

#main-header h1 {
  margin: 0;
  color: #255b5b;
}

/* =========================
   NAVIGATION (desktop default)
   ========================= */
#main-nav ul {
  list-style: none;
  padding: 0;
  margin: 12px auto 0;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  gap: 12px;
}

#main-nav li {
  background: #d98a8a;
  border-radius: 4px;
}

#main-nav a {
  display: block;
  padding: 10px 16px;
  color: white;
  text-decoration: none;
  font-weight: bold;
}

/* =========================
   MAIN CONTENT
   ========================= */
main {
  padding: 20px 0;
}

/* =========================
   TOP ROW (SIDE-BY-SIDE)
   ========================= */
.top-row {
  display: flex;
  gap: 24px;
  align-items: flex-start;
}

/* Left text */
.intro.one {
  flex: 2;
}

.intro.one h2 {
  color: #2f6f6f;
  margin-top: 0;
}

/* Right cards */
.cards.two {
  flex: 3;
  display: flex;
  gap: 16px;
  justify-content: flex-end;
}

.card {
  flex: 0 0 140px;
  text-align: center;
}

.card h3 {
  margin: 0 0 8px 0;
  background: #2f6f6f;
  color: white;
  padding: 8px 0;
  border-radius: 4px;
  font-size: 0.9rem;
}

.card img {
  width: 100%;
  max-width: 140px;
  border: 3px solid #aac1bf;
  background: #9fb4b4;
}

/* =========================
   FEATURES (ROWS BELOW)
   ========================= */
.features {
  margin-top: 24px;
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  gap: 18px;
}

.feature {
  display: flex;
  gap: 14px;
  align-items: center;
  background: #2f6f6f;
  color: white;
  padding: 14px;
  border-radius: 4px;
}

.feature.reversed {
  flex-direction: row-reverse;
}

.feature .feat-left,
.feature .feat-right {
  flex: 0 0 140px;
  text-align: center;
}

.feature .feat-mid {
  flex: 1;
  padding: 12px;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.06);
}

.feature img {
  width: 120px;
  border: 3px solid rgba(255,255,255,0.15);
  background: #9fb4b4;
}

/* =========================
   FOOTER
   ========================= */
#main-footer {
  margin-top: 20px;
  padding: 12px;
  text-align: center;
  background: #d98a8a;
  color: white;
  border-radius: 6px;
}

/* =========================
   MOBILE LAYOUT
   ========================= */
@media (max-width: 768px) {

  /* Nav becomes vertical */
  #main-nav ul {
    flex-direction: column;
    width: 90%;
  }

  /* Stack top row */
  .top-row {
    flex-direction: column;
  }

  /* Stack cards */
  .cards.two {
    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: center;
  }

  .card {
    max-width: 260px;
  }

  /* Stack feature rows */
  .feature,
  .feature.reversed {
    flex-direction: column;
    text-align: center;
  }
}

WHAT THIS WILL SHOW

On your laptop / desktop:

  • Horizontal navbar

  • Left intro text

  • Four cards in a row on the right

  • Three horizontal feature rows underneath

On small screens:

  • Vertical navbar

  • Stacked intro + cards

  • Stacked feature rows

FINAL STEP

  1. Save styles.css

  2. Hard refresh the page

    • Windows: Ctrl + F5

    • Mac: Cmd + Shift + R

If you want, next I can:

  • confirm this matches the diagram line by line, or

  • help you push Assignment 3 to GitHub, or

  • add the Assignment 3 link to your main page

bash

  • add an Assignments gallery (with screenshots + short unique descriptions),

  • add a Projects section (with screenshot + link to your topic PDF),

  • keep everything responsive with Flexbox and a media query,

  • and push the changes to GitHub.

Do not change anything except the files I name below. Ill show exactly where to put screenshots and the exact HTML/CSS to paste.

1) Where files go (exact)

Repository structure (only list files youll edit/add):

kotlin
csce242/
  index.html                 your main portal page (well update this)
  styles.css                 main stylesheet (well update this)
  assignments/
    01-basic-html/
      index.html

Use exactly those filenames (screenshot.png) so the HTML code below points to valid files.

2) How to make and resize screenshots (super quick)

On Windows

  1. Open the page in your browser (local file or GitHub Pages).

  2. Press Windows type Snipping Tool or Snip & Sketch and take a rectangular snip of the page.

  3. Save as screenshot.png into the folder for that assignment: e.g. csce242/assignments/01-basic-html/screenshot.png.

  4. To resize: open Paint Open the screenshot Resize choose Pixels set Width = 600 (example) and keep aspect ratio Save.

On Mac

  1. Open page in browser.

  2. Press Cmd + Shift + 4 select area file saved to Desktop.

  3. Open in Preview Tools Adjust Size set width to 600px (or whatever size you want) Save into the assignment folder.

Quick guidelines

  • Make all screenshots the same width (I recommend 600px wide). Height can vary.

  • Save as screenshot.png in each assignment/project folder.

  • If you prefer an online resizer, use any free site (search resize image) keep images moderate size.

3) Exact HTML to put in csce242/index.html

Open csce242/index.html and find where your Assignments list is. Replace the Assignments list area and add the Projects section with this full block (it uses semantic elements and matches instructions). If you already had an assignment list above, you can replace the <ol>/assignment area with the block below.

Paste this where you want the Assignments + Projects to appear (between your course description and footer):

html
<!-- Assignments + Projects Block (replace existing assignments list with this) -->
<section id="work-portal">

  <h2 id="assignments-heading">Assignments</h2>

  <div id="assignments-gallery" class="gallery">
    <!-- Assignment 1 -->
    <article class="card">
      <a href="assignments/01-basic-html/index.html">
        <img src="assignments/01-basic-html/screenshot.png" alt="Assignment 1 screenshot">
      </a>
      <h3><a href="assignments/01-basic-html/index.html">01  Basic HTML</a></h3>
      <p class="desc">A simple, semantic HTML page about breakfast with two paragraphs, a table, list, and images. I wrote the content and formatted elements from scratch to meet the class rules.</p>
    </article>

    <!-- Assignment 2 -->
    <article class="card">
      <a href="assignments/02-styled-site/index.html">
        <img src="assignments/02-styled-site/screenshot.png" alt="Assignment 2 screenshot">
      </a>
      <h3><a href="assignments/02-styled-site/index.html">02  Styled Site</a></h3>
      <p class="desc">A styled portal and second site that demonstrates CSS theming: background image, custom fonts, a readable content container, and styled tables and images.</p>
    </article>

    <!-- Assignment 3 -->
    <article class="card">
      <a href="assignments/03-page-layout/index.html">
        <img src="assignments/03-page-layout/screenshot.png" alt="Assignment 3 screenshot">
      </a>
      <h3><a href="assignments/03-page-layout/index.html">03  Page Layout with Flex</a></h3>
      <p class="desc">A responsive layout built with CSS Flexbox. The design switches between a two-column desktop layout and a stacked mobile layout using a media query.</p>
    </article>
  </div>

  <h2 id="projects-heading">Projects</h2>

  <div id="projects-gallery" class="gallery">
    <!-- Project Part 1 -->
    <article class="card">
      <a href="projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf" target="_blank">
        <img src="projects/part1/screenshot.png" alt="Project Part 1 screenshot">
      </a>
      <h3><a href="projects/part1/project-part1-topic-selection.pdf" target="_blank">Project  Topic Selection (Part 1)</a></h3>
      <p class="desc">Project part 1: Topic selection for my website project about breakfasts. Includes the description of data and planned pages. PDF link opens in a new tab.</p>
    </article>
  </div>

</section>

Notes:

  • The img src paths assume you saved screenshots as screenshot.png in each folder.

  • Add more <article class="card"> blocks for future assignments/projects (same pattern).

4) Exact CSS to add to csce242/styles.css

Open csce242/styles.css (your main site stylesheet) and append the following CSS near the end (or paste entire file if you prefer). This code uses Flexbox for gallery, cards, consistent sizing, and a media query to stack on small screens:

css
/* ---------- Assignments & Projects gallery ---------- */
#work-portal {
  margin-top: 30px;
}

/* Section titles */
#assignments-heading,
#projects-heading {
  font-size: 1.4rem;
  color: #2f6f6f;
  margin: 18px 0 10px;
}

/* gallery container (flex row, wraps) */
.gallery {
  display: flex;
  gap: 18px;
  flex-wrap: wrap;
  align-items: flex-start;
}

/* individual card */
.card {
  width: 320px;               /* card width (controls image size) */
  background: #ffffff;
  border-radius: 6px;
  padding: 8px;
  box-shadow: 0 1px 4px rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  gap: 8px;
}

/* screenshot image */
.card img {
  width: 100%;
  height: auto;
  border-radius: 4px;
  display: block;
  object-fit: cover;
  border: 2px solid #e6e6e6;
}

/* titles & links */
.card h3 {
  margin: 0;
  font-size: 1rem;
}
.card h3 a {
  text-decoration: none;
  color: #204245;
  font-weight: 700;
}

/* description */
.card .desc {
  margin: 0;
  color: #444;
  font-size: 0.95rem;
  line-height: 1.35;
}

/* projects gallery spacing (same style as assignments) */
#projects-gallery { margin-top: 12px; }

/* responsive: stack cards and columns for small screens */
@media (max-width: 768px) {
  .gallery {
    flex-direction: column;
    gap: 14px;
  }
  .card {
    width: 100%;            /* full width on small screens */
  }
}

This CSS:

  • Makes each card 320px wide (you can change width to 280 if you prefer smaller).

  • Uses the same visual style for assignments and projects.

  • Stacks cards vertically below 768px.

5) Quick checklist to complete before pushing

  1. Take and resize screenshots for each assignment and project (see instructions above). Save them as:

    • csce242/assignments/01-basic-html/screenshot.png

    • csce242/assignments/02-styled-site/screenshot.png

    • csce242/assignments/03-page-layout/screenshot.png

    • csce242/projects/part1/screenshot.png

  2. Edit csce242/index.html and replace the assignments/projects area with the HTML block in step 3.

  3. Append the new CSS to csce242/styles.css (step 4).

  4. Preview locally: open csce242/index.html in your browser. Check both wide and narrow widths.

6) Git commands to add screenshots and push (exact)

In VS Code terminal:

bash
# stage the updated main page and CSS plus new screenshots and PDF if needed
git add csce242/index.html csce242/styles.css
git add csce242/assignments/01-basic-html/screenshot.png
git add csce242/assignments/02-styled-site/screenshot.png
git add csce242/assignments/03-page-layout/screenshot.png
git add csce242/projects/part1/screenshot.png

git commit -m "Update main portal: assignments & projects gallery with screenshots and descriptions"
git push

If you already committed screenshots earlier, git add will skip unchanged ones. If git asks for authentication, sign in to GitHub.

7) Extra tiny tips (grading-safe)

  • Use unique descriptions (12 short sentences) for each assignment the professor required that.

  • Keep screenshot images clear but not huge 600900px wide before resizing is fine; final card width is 320px.

  • The Projects PDF link must be public (you already uploaded it to GitHub earlier); verify the link opens in a new tab.
